canonical_explanation.text: A globe is a small model of the Earth. It is round like a ball because the Earth is shaped like a sphere. A globe shows us all the continents and oceans. It spins on an axis, just like the Earth. A map is a flat drawing of the Earth or a part of it on paper. Maps can show the whole world, a country, a state, a city, or even a neighbourhood. There are different types of maps: physical maps show mountains, rivers, and plains; political maps show countries, states, and cities; and road maps show roads and highways. The globe and maps show 7 continents: Asia (the largest, where India is), Africa, North America, South America, Antarctica (the coldest), Europe, and Australia (the smallest). There are 5 oceans: Pacific Ocean (largest), Atlantic Ocean, Indian Ocean, Arctic Ocean (smallest), and Southern Ocean. On a map, there are four main directions: North (N), South (S), East (E), and West (W). The sun rises in the East and sets in the West. Maps use symbols to show different things: blue for water, green for forests, brown for mountains, black dots for cities, and lines for roads and rivers. A compass rose on a map shows the directions. The legend or key of a map explains what each symbol means. Learning to read maps helps us find places and understand the world around us.
rules: A globe is a round model of the Earth
A map is a flat drawing of the Earth or part of it on paper
There are 7 continents: Asia, Africa, North America, South America, Antarctica, Europe, Australia
Asia is the largest continent; India is in Asia
There are 5 oceans: Pacific (largest), Atlantic, Indian, Arctic (smallest), Southern
Four main directions: North, South, East, West
The sun rises in the East and sets in the West
Map symbols: blue for water, green for forests, brown for mountains
A compass rose shows directions on a map
A legend or key explains map symbols

questions.question_text: What is a globe?

options.text: A flat drawing of the Earth
A round model of the Earth

questions.explanation_correct: A globe is a round (spherical) model of the Earth. It shows us how the Earth really looks from space — round, with continents and oceans. It spins on an axis just like the real Earth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A flat drawing of the Earth is a map, not a globe. A globe is not a book or a picture of the sun. It is a round model that represents our planet Earth.

questions.question_text: Why is a globe round?

options.text: Because it is easier to carry
Because the Earth is shaped like a sphere
Because all models must be round

questions.explanation_correct: A globe is round because it is a model of the Earth, and the Earth is shaped like a sphere (ball). A globe shows the true shape of the Earth better than a flat map can.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A globe is not round for convenience. The Earth is not flat. Not all models are round. The globe is round because it represents the round shape of our planet Earth.

questions.question_text: What is a map?

options.text: A flat drawing of the Earth or a part of it

questions.explanation_correct: A map is a flat drawing of the Earth or a part of the Earth on paper or a screen. Maps can show the whole world, a country, a state, a city, or even just a school or neighbourhood.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A round model is a globe, not a map. A map is not a photograph or a type of globe. A map is a flat representation of the Earth or part of it.

questions.question_text: True or False: A globe shows the Earth's shape more accurately than a flat map.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Since the Earth is round, a globe shows its shape more accurately than a flat map. When we flatten a round surface, some distortion (stretching or squishing) happens.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is correct. A globe gives a more accurate representation of Earth's shape because both the globe and Earth are spherical.

questions.question_text: Riya wants to see exactly how India looks compared to other countries in terms of shape and size. Should she use a globe or a flat map?

options.text: A flat map, because it is easier to carry
A globe, because it shows shapes and sizes more accurately

questions.explanation_correct: A globe would be better for seeing accurate shapes and sizes because the Earth is round. Flat maps can distort (stretch or squish) the shapes and sizes of countries.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While flat maps are easier to carry, a globe is more accurate for comparing shapes and sizes. A dictionary or guessing would not help at all.

questions.question_text: How many continents are there on Earth?
questions.explanation_correct: There are 7 continents on Earth: Asia, Africa, North America, South America, Antarctica, Europe, and Australia (also called Oceania). A continent is a very large area of land.
questions.explanation_incorrect: There are not 5, 6, or 8 continents. The correct number is 7: Asia, Africa, North America, South America, Antarctica, Europe, and Australia.

questions.question_text: Which is the largest continent?
questions.explanation_correct: Asia is the largest continent in the world, both by area and population. India is located in Asia. China, Japan, and many other countries are also in Asia.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Africa is the second largest, Europe is much smaller, and North America is third. Asia is the largest continent in the world.

questions.question_text: India is located in which continent?
questions.explanation_correct: India is located in Asia, the largest continent. Specifically, India is in the southern part of Asia, called South Asia. Other South Asian countries include Pakistan, Bangladesh, Nepal, and Sri Lanka.
questions.explanation_incorrect: India is not in Africa, Europe, or Australia. India is in Asia, specifically in the South Asian region.

questions.question_text: Which continent is the coldest?
questions.explanation_correct: Antarctica is the coldest continent. It is located at the South Pole and is covered with ice and snow all year round. Penguins live in Antarctica, but very few people live there.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Asia, Africa, and Europe all have warm areas. Antarctica at the South Pole is the coldest continent on Earth, with temperatures that can drop below minus 80 degrees Celsius.

questions.question_text: Which is the smallest continent?
questions.explanation_correct: Australia is the smallest continent. It is also a country — the only continent that is a single country. It is sometimes called Oceania when including the nearby islands.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Europe is small but not the smallest. Antarctica and South America are larger. Australia is the smallest continent in the world.

questions.question_text: There are __________ oceans on Earth.
questions.explanation_correct: There are 5 oceans on Earth: Pacific Ocean (largest), Atlantic Ocean, Indian Ocean, Arctic Ocean (smallest), and Southern Ocean. Oceans cover most of the Earth's surface.
questions.explanation_incorrect: There are not 3, 4, or 7 oceans. The correct number is 5: Pacific, Atlantic, Indian, Arctic, and Southern.

questions.question_text: Which is the largest ocean?
questions.explanation_correct: The Pacific Ocean is the largest ocean in the world. It covers more area than all the land on Earth combined! It stretches from Asia and Australia to the Americas.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Indian, Atlantic, and Arctic Oceans are smaller. The Pacific Ocean is the largest, covering about one-third of the Earth's surface.

questions.question_text: True or False: The Arctic Ocean is the smallest ocean.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. The Arctic Ocean is the smallest and shallowest of the five oceans. It is located around the North Pole and is largely covered with ice.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is correct. The Arctic Ocean at the North Pole is indeed the smallest ocean.

questions.question_text: Which ocean is named after our country India?
questions.explanation_correct: The Indian Ocean is named after India! It is the third largest ocean and is located to the south of India. India is the only country after which an ocean is named.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Pacific and Atlantic Oceans are not named after India. The Arctic Ocean is near the North Pole. The Indian Ocean is the one named after our country.

questions.question_text: What are the four main directions?
questions.explanation_correct: The four main directions (also called cardinal directions) are North, South, East, and West. These directions help us navigate and find places on maps and in real life.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Up/down/left/right and the other options are everyday directions but not the four main compass directions. North, South, East, and West are the four cardinal directions.

questions.question_text: The sun rises in the:
questions.explanation_correct: The sun rises in the East every morning. This is a good way to remember directions — if you face the rising sun, East is in front of you, West is behind, North is to your left, and South is to your right.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The sun does not rise in the North, South, or West. It rises in the East and sets in the West every day.

questions.question_text: The sun sets in the:
questions.explanation_correct: The sun sets in the West every evening. This is the opposite direction from where it rises (East). Remembering sunrise (East) and sunset (West) helps us learn directions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The sun does not set in the East, North, or South. It always sets in the West, which is the opposite direction from where it rises.

questions.question_text: True or False: If you face North, East is to your right.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. If you face North: East is to your right, West is to your left, and South is behind you. This is a helpful way to remember the four directions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is correct. When facing North, East is on your right side. You can remember this by the clockwise order: North, East, South, West.

questions.question_text: Aman is walking towards the rising sun. Which direction is he walking?
questions.explanation_correct: Since the sun rises in the East, Aman is walking towards the East. If you walk towards the rising sun, you are heading East. If you walk towards the setting sun, you are heading West.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The sun rises in the East, not in the North, South, or West. So if Aman is walking towards the rising sun, he is walking East.

questions.question_text: What does a compass rose on a map show?
questions.explanation_correct: A compass rose is a symbol on a map that shows the four main directions: North, South, East, and West. It usually looks like a star with the letters N, S, E, and W.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A compass rose does not show country names, distances, or colours. It specifically shows the directions on a map so you know which way is north, south, east, and west.

questions.question_text: On most maps, which colour represents water (oceans, rivers, lakes)?
questions.explanation_correct: Blue is used on maps to show water — oceans, seas, rivers, and lakes are all shown in blue. This is because water appears blue in real life.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Green usually shows forests. Brown shows mountains or highlands. Red might show borders or roads. Blue is the colour used for all water bodies on maps.

questions.question_text: On a map, green colour usually represents:
questions.explanation_correct: Green on a map usually represents forests, vegetation, and lowlands (flat, low-lying areas). The darker the green, the denser the forest.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Water is shown in blue. Mountains are usually brown. Roads are shown with lines. Green represents forests and lowlands on maps.

questions.question_text: On a physical map, brown colour usually represents:
questions.explanation_correct: Brown on a physical map represents mountains and highlands (high areas). The darker the brown, the higher the land. The Himalayas would appear as dark brown on a physical map of India.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rivers are blue. Forests are green. Oceans are blue. Brown represents mountains and highlands on physical maps.

questions.question_text: What is the 'legend' or 'key' on a map?

options.text: A list that explains what the symbols on the map mean
The name of the map maker
A lock to keep the map safe

questions.explanation_correct: A legend (or key) is a list on a map that explains what each symbol, colour, and line means. For example, it might show that a blue line means a river, a green area means forest, and a dot means a city.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The legend is not a story, the mapmaker's name, or a lock. It is the explanation box that tells you what all the symbols and colours on the map represent.

questions.question_text: True or False: On a map, a small black dot often represents a city.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. On many maps, small black dots are used to show the location of cities. A slightly larger dot or a star might be used for capital cities. The map legend explains what each symbol means.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is correct. Black dots are commonly used on maps to mark the location of cities and towns.

questions.question_text: A teacher wants to show her class the route from their school to the zoo. Should she use a globe or a map?

options.text: A globe, because it is round
A map, because it can show streets and routes in detail

questions.explanation_correct: A map would be better because it can show streets, roads, and routes in detail. A globe shows the whole Earth and cannot show small details like individual streets and buildings.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A globe is too large-scale to show streets. Neither and a dictionary are unhelpful. A map is the right choice because it can zoom in and show detailed routes.

questions.question_text: If you look at a globe and see a lot of blue, what does all that blue represent?
questions.explanation_correct: The blue on a globe represents water — oceans and seas. About 71% (almost three-quarters) of the Earth's surface is covered with water, which is why a globe looks mostly blue.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The blue on a globe is not sky, forests, or mountains. It represents water (oceans and seas). Most of Earth's surface is water, which is why the globe looks so blue.

questions.question_text: Nita is standing and her shadow is pointing towards the West in the morning. She must be facing:
questions.explanation_correct: In the morning, the sun is in the East. Shadows fall opposite to the sun's direction. If Nita's shadow points West, the sun must be in front of her (East), so she is facing East.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If a shadow falls to the West in the morning (when the sun is in the East), the person must be facing East, towards the sun. Shadows always fall away from the sun.

questions.question_text: Which list correctly names all 7 continents?

options.text: Asia, Africa, Europe, India, Australia, Antarctica, South America
Asia, Africa, North America, South America, Antarctica, Europe, Australia
Asia, Pacific, Atlantic, Europe, Africa, Australia, Antarctica
India, China, Africa, America, Europe, Australia, Antarctica

questions.explanation_correct: The 7 continents are: Asia, Africa, North America, South America, Antarctica, Europe, and Australia. India and China are countries within Asia, not separate continents. Pacific and Atlantic are oceans, not continents.
questions.explanation_incorrect: India is a country in Asia, not a continent. Pacific and Atlantic are oceans. The correct list is: Asia, Africa, North America, South America, Antarctica, Europe, and Australia.

questions.question_text: Raj is looking at a map but cannot understand the symbols. What should he look at to understand them?
questions.explanation_correct: Raj should look at the legend (or key) of the map. The legend explains what each symbol, colour, and line on the map means. It is like a guide to reading the map.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The title tells the name of the map. The compass rose shows directions. The back may be blank. The legend (key) is specifically designed to explain map symbols.

questions.question_text: __________ is the largest continent in the world.
questions.explanation_correct: Asia is the largest continent in the world. It covers about 30% of the Earth's total land area and is home to more than half of the world's population, including India.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Africa is the second largest. North America and Europe are smaller. Asia is the largest continent by both area and population.

questions.question_text: On a standard map, North is usually at the:
questions.explanation_correct: On most standard maps, North is at the top, South is at the bottom, East is on the right, and West is on the left. This is a convention (agreed rule) that map makers follow.
questions.explanation_incorrect: North is not at the bottom, left, or right of a standard map. By convention, North is always placed at the top of a standard map.

questions.question_text: What is one advantage of a map over a globe?

options.text: A map shows Earth's shape better
A map can show small areas in great detail

questions.explanation_correct: A map can show small areas (like a city or neighbourhood) in great detail, which a globe cannot do. Maps can also be folded and carried easily, and printed in books.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A globe shows Earth's shape better, not a map. A map is flat, not round. Maps do show directions. The advantage of maps is they can show small areas in great detail.

questions.question_text: A political map is used to show:

options.text: Countries, states, and cities with their borders
Types of animals in an area

questions.explanation_correct: A political map shows countries, states, and cities along with their borders (boundaries). Different countries or states are usually shown in different colours to make them easy to identify.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mountains and rivers are shown on physical maps. Weather is shown on weather maps. Animals are shown on special maps. Political maps specifically show countries, states, cities, and borders.

questions.question_text: A physical map is used to show:

options.text: Mountains, rivers, plains, and other landforms

questions.explanation_correct: A physical map shows natural features of the land like mountains, rivers, plains, plateaus, deserts, and oceans. It uses colours and shading to show different heights and depths.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Country borders are on political maps. Railways are on transport maps. Population is on special maps. Physical maps specifically show natural landforms like mountains, rivers, and plains.

questions.question_text: True or False: If you face the setting sun, you are facing West.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. The sun sets in the West. So if you face the setting sun, you are facing West. Behind you would be East, to your right would be North, and to your left would be South.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is correct. Since the sun sets in the West, facing the setting sun means you are facing West.

questions.question_text: Africa is separated from Europe by a small body of water. Which continent has the most countries?
questions.explanation_correct: Africa has the most countries — 54 in total. While Asia is the largest continent by area, Africa has more individual countries than any other continent.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Although Asia is the largest, Africa actually has the most countries at 54. Europe, North America, and South America all have fewer countries than Africa.

questions.question_text: What are the directions between the four main directions called? (e.g., between North and East)
questions.explanation_correct: The directions between the four main directions are called intermediate or inter-cardinal directions. They are: North-East (NE), North-West (NW), South-East (SE), and South-West (SW).
questions.explanation_incorrect: They are not called side, hidden, or secret directions. The directions between the main four are intermediate (or inter-cardinal) directions: NE, NW, SE, SW.

questions.question_text: On a map, Sita sees a thin blue line going through her city. What does it most likely represent?
questions.explanation_correct: A thin blue line on a map most likely represents a river. Blue is used for water on maps. A thick blue area would be an ocean or lake, and a thin blue line would be a river or stream.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Highways are usually shown as black or red lines. Railways are shown with special line symbols. Borders are usually dotted or dashed lines. A blue line represents a river.

questions.question_text: The __________ Ocean is named after our country.
questions.explanation_correct: The Indian Ocean is named after India. It is the third largest ocean in the world and lies to the south of India. India is the only country in the world that has an ocean named after it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Pacific, Atlantic, and Arctic oceans are not named after India. Only the Indian Ocean carries our country's name.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a difference between a globe and a map?

options.text: A globe is flat and a map is round
A globe is round and a map is flat
A map cannot show any place

questions.explanation_correct: A globe is round (spherical) and a map is flat. This is the main difference. A globe shows the Earth's true shape, while a map is a flat representation that is easier to use for details.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A globe is round, not flat. A map is flat, not round. They are not the same. Maps can show many places. The key difference is the shape: globe = round, map = flat.

questions.question_text: Rani is facing North. Her friend asks her to turn right. Which direction is she now facing?
questions.explanation_correct: If Rani faces North and turns right, she faces East. Think of a compass: clockwise from North is East. If she turned left from North, she would face West.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Turning right from North does not lead to South, West, or keep you facing North. Right from North is East (clockwise direction).

questions.question_text: True or False: More than two-thirds of the Earth's surface is covered with water.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. About 71% of the Earth's surface is covered with water (oceans, seas, lakes, rivers). That is why the Earth is sometimes called the 'Blue Planet' — because it looks blue from space.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is correct. About 71% (nearly three-quarters) of Earth is covered with water, which is why our planet appears blue from space.

questions.question_text: Which type of map would you use to plan a road trip?
questions.explanation_correct: A road map would be best for planning a road trip because it shows roads, highways, distances between places, and important landmarks. It helps you find the best route to your destination.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A physical map shows landforms. A political map shows borders. A weather map shows weather. A road map is specifically designed for travel, showing roads and distances.

questions.question_text: Which ocean lies between North America and Europe?
questions.explanation_correct: The Atlantic Ocean lies between the continents of North America (and South America) on the west and Europe (and Africa) on the east. It is the second largest ocean after the Pacific.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Pacific Ocean is between Asia and the Americas. The Indian Ocean is south of Asia. The Arctic is at the North Pole. The Atlantic Ocean is between the Americas and Europe/Africa.

questions.question_text: Why is the Earth sometimes called the 'Blue Planet'?

options.text: Because most of its surface is covered with water, which looks blue from space
Because it is near a blue star

questions.explanation_correct: The Earth is called the 'Blue Planet' because about 71% of its surface is covered with water (oceans and seas). When seen from space, all this water makes the Earth look blue and beautiful.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Earth is not painted blue or near a blue star. While the sky is blue, that is not why Earth is called the Blue Planet. It is because the vast oceans make it look blue from space.

questions.question_text: The symbol on a map that shows directions is called a __________.
questions.explanation_correct: The compass rose is the symbol on a map that shows directions (North, South, East, West). It is usually shaped like a star or flower with arrows pointing to the four directions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The legend explains symbols. The scale shows distances. The title gives the map's name. The compass rose specifically shows directions on a map.

questions.question_text: Arjun faces East. He turns left. Then turns left again. Which direction does he now face?
questions.explanation_correct: Arjun starts facing East. Turning left (counter-clockwise) once, he faces North. Turning left again, he faces West. Two left turns from East equal facing West (opposite direction).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Starting East, turning left once gives North, turning left again gives West. Two left turns always make you face the opposite direction: East becomes West.

questions.question_text: Penguins are found in Antarctica. Looking at a globe, where is Antarctica?
questions.explanation_correct: Antarctica is at the very bottom of the globe, at the South Pole. It is the coldest continent and is covered with ice. Penguins, seals, and whales are found there.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The North Pole is the Arctic (no continent there, just ice). The middle has the equator. Antarctica is not near India. It is at the very bottom of the globe, at the South Pole.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is needed to read a map correctly?

options.text: Understanding the compass rose, legend, and symbols

questions.explanation_correct: To read a map correctly, you need to understand the compass rose (for directions), the legend/key (for what symbols mean), and the various map symbols (colours, lines, dots). These are the tools for map reading.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A magnifying glass, calculator, or telescope are not essential for reading maps. Understanding the compass rose, legend, and symbols are the key skills needed for map reading.
